sen.j: 院宮給（いんぐうきゅう）とは、太上天皇と三宮 (后妃)に給する年官と年爵のこと。
sen.e: Ingu kyu is the nenkan (a right granted as a stipend to members of the Imperial family (including the emperor), consorts of the emperor, some Court nobles, and so forth to nominate a person for a certain government post conferred to them on the occasion of the annual installation of them as government officials) and nenshaku (a right granted as a stipend to a retired emperor, the mother of the Emperor Dowager, the Empress Dowager, the Empress, and so forth to nominate a person for a certain rank conferred to them on the occasion of the annual conferment of a rank to them a right granted as a stipend to members) given to Daijo tenno (the Retired Emperor) and Sannomiya (empress).

Ingu kyu is a nenkan (a right granted as a stipend to members of the Imperial family (including the emperor), consorts of the emperor, some Court nobles, and so forth in order to nominate a person for a certain government post conferred on occasion of an annual installation as a government official) and a nenshaku (a right granted as a stipend to a retired emperor, the mother of the Emperor Dowager, the Empress Dowager, the Empress, and so forth in order to nominate a person for a certain rank on occasions of annual conferments of ranks) given to Daijo tenno (the Retired Emperor) and Sannomiya (empress).
sen.cmt: eliminated "a right granted as a stipend to members" since it was already written similarly at the beginning of the parenthetical description of "nenshaku";
sen.e: Ingu kyu is a nenkan (a right granted as a stipend to members of the Imperial family (including the emperor), consorts of the emperor, some Court nobles, and so forth in order to nominate a person for a certain government post conferred on occasion of an annual installation as a government official) and a nenshaku (a right granted as a stipend to a retired emperor, the mother of the Emperor Dowager, the Empress Dowager, the Empress, and so forth in order to nominate a person for a certain rank on occasions of annual conferments of ranks) given to Daijo tenno (the Retired Emperor) and Sannomiya (empress).

sen.j: 特に御給（おんきゅう）とも呼び、親王以下の人給と区別した。
sen.e: It was also called Onkyu or Gokyu (a kind of payment paid to members of the Imperial family) and was separated from the kyuden (provided rice field) given to those whose ranks were lower than the Imperial prince.
sen.cmt: 「人給」の意味がわからなかったのですが、「人給」というのは「人給田、給田」を指すということなので、「給田」として訳しました。
sen.e: It was also called Onkyu or Gokyu (a kind of payment paid to members of the Imperial family) and was separate from kyuden (provided rice field) given to those with rank lower than the Imperial prince.

It was also called Onkyu or Gokyu (a kind of payment paid to members of the Imperial family) and was separate from kyuden (provided rice field) given to those with rank lower than the Imperial prince.

sen.j: また、准后に叙せられた人臣に対してもこれに準じた待遇が与えられた。
sen.e: Also, the subjects who had been conferred Jugo (or Jusango, an honorary rank next to Emperor, Empress Dowager, and Empress, conferred to both men and women) received treatment accordingly.
Furthermore, subjects who were conferred Jugo (or Jusango, an honorary rank next to the Emperor, Empress Dowager, and Empress, conferred to both men and women) received treatment accordingly.
Furthermore, subjects who were conferred Jugo (or Jusango, an honorary rank next to the Emperor, Empress Dowager, and Empress, conferred to both men and women) received treatment accordingly.

sen.j: 院宮給の成立については諸説あるが、三宮への年官は淳和天皇の頃に成立し、残りの三宮の年爵・院の年官・年爵も宇多上皇が院宮給のありかたについて触れた『寛平御遺誡』が成立した寛平年間には既に存在していた。
sen.e: Although there are various theories on when ingu kyu was established, nenkyu for Sannomiya was set up during the era of Emperor Junna, while the nenshaku for the remaining Sannomiya, nenkan and nenshaku for In already existed in the Kampyo era when "Kampyo-Goyuikai/Kampyo-no-Goyuikai" (a group of precepts for governing), in which the retired Emperor Uda mentioned what ingu kyu should be, was completed.

Although there are various theories on when Ingu kyu was established, nenkyu for Sannomiya came into existence during the era of Emperor Junna. Whereas nenshaku for the Sannomiya, as well as nenkan and nenshaku for In, had already existed in the Kampyo era after "Kampyo-Goyuikai/Kampyo-no-Goyuikai" (a group of precepts for governing) was established and the retired Emperor Uda mentioned what he thought should be the ingu kyu.
sen.cmt: eliminated "remaining" since it was awkward and unecessary; split into two sentences as this was just too long as one; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Although there are various theories on when Ingu kyu was established, nenkan for Sannomiya came into existence during the era of Emperor Junna, while nenshaku for the Sannomiya, as well as nenkan and nenshaku for In, had already existed in the Kampyo era after "Kampyo-Goyuikai/Kampyo-no-Goyuikai" (a group of precepts for governing) was established and the retired Emperor Uda mentioned what he thought should be the ingu kyu.

sen.j: 院宮給は年爵（従五位下）1名・内官1名・国司の掾1名・同じく目1名・史生3名、後に女爵1名が追加された。
sen.e: 1 person for Nenshaku (Jugoinoge), 1 naikan (a government official who resided in Kyoto), 1 assistant to kokushi (provincial governor), 1 Sakan (secretary) to kokushi, 1 Shisho (a person doing miscellaneous duties about documents) were added to the beneficiaries of ingu kyu, and later 1 nyoshaku was added.

One person for Nenshaku (Jugoinoge), one naikan (a government official who resided in Kyoto), one assistant to kokushi (provincial governor), one Sakan (secretary) to kokushi, one Shisho (a person doing miscellaneous duties about documents) were added to the beneficiaries of Ingu kyu, and one nyoshaku was added later on.
sen.cmt: changed numerals to words; fixed grammar
sen.e: One person for Nenshaku (Jugoinoge), one naikan (a government official who resided in Kyoto), one assistant to kokushi (provincial governor), one Sakan (secretary) to kokushi, one Shisho (a person doing miscellaneous duties about documents) were added to the beneficiaries of Ingu kyu, and one nyoshaku was added later on.

sen.j: 年爵や内官（京官）は収入が多く、推挙の見返りとして被任命者から送られる収入も多かった。
sen.e: People who were granted nenshaku and naikan (kyokan) enjoyed high income, as well as a large income from the appointees in exchange for recommendation.
Those who were granted nenshaku and naikan (kyokan) enjoyed a large income from their position as well from appointees in exchange for recommendations.
Those who were granted nenshaku and naikan (kyokan) enjoyed a large income from their position as well from appointees in exchange for recommendations.

sen.j: これは人給には見られないものである。
sen.e: This was not the case with ninkyu
This was not the case with ninkyu
This was not the case with ninkyu

sen.j: だが、国家財政の逼迫と地方政治の衰微によって収入が減少すると、臨時給や合爵（官職への推挙権を返上する代わりに、より実入りのある年爵を1名分増加させる）などの措置も取られた。
sen.e: But when the revenue dropped due to the nation's hard-pressed economy and the decline of local governments, a measure, among others, was taken to add a portion for one person to nenshaku.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: When the revenue dropped due to the nation's hard-pressed economy and decline of local governments, however, such measures were taken to add a portion for one person to nenshaku.
sen.cmt: changed "But" to "however" and used later in the sentence; fixed grammar
sen.e: When the revenue dropped due to the nation's hard-pressed economy and decline of local governments, however, such measures were taken to add a portion for one person to nenshaku.

sen.j: それでも不足したために院宮分国制の導入や年爵で推挙できる位階の引き上げ（院政期には公卿である従三位まで推挙可能となる）なども行われるようになった。
sen.e: Still, due to the insufficient revenue, Ingu bunkoku sei (provincial allotment system) was introduced and ikai (Court rank) was raised (up to Jusanmi (junior Third Rank), a Court noble during insei period (period of the government by the retired Emperor)).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Still, due to the insufficient revenue, Ingu bunkoku sei (provincial allotment system) was introduced and ikai (Court rank) was raised (up to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) for Court nobles during insei period (period of the government by the retired Emperor)).

Still, due to the insufficient revenue, Ingu bunkoku sei (provincial allotment system) was introduced and ikai (Court rank) was raised (up to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) for Court nobles during insei period (period of the government by the retired Emperor)).
